sense.name: direct and discharge something at someone or something
sense.examples: The hunter fired at the target. Gun fired once at the target. The hunter fired the gun at the target. Gun was fired at the target. This gun fires fake bullets. Fire away! Fire away your questions and complaints! The pitcher fired a ball at the batter. The pitcher wound up and fired. The reporters fired questions at the senator. The reporters fired away all evening. In a normal brain, neurons fire at their own speed, randomly. Between 1824 and 1846, editorial columns fired insults back and forth.

sense.name: dismiss somebody from employment
sense.examples: The boss fired his secretary today. He was fired for chatting online at work. I cannot believe that he was fired for talking about the South Dakota.

sense.name: excite or evoke strong emotion
sense.examples: The warriors were fired by patriotism. They were surely fired with enthusiasm. Everyone was fired up with enthusiasm.

sense.name: ignite or become ignited
sense.examples: The engines fire with a force nearly five times that of gravity. He fired up the furnace. Oil fired the furnace. Simon fired up his cigar and stared, deliberately, out of the window. And she piqued my curiosity and my curiosity fired my imagination. Visiting places of historical interest fires your imagination surely.

sense.name: burn something with fire
sense.examples: They fired the couch and waited round to see it burn. The morning sun fired the tops of the trees. Then he fired the wood blocks in a furnace at 1400 C.

sense.name: bake to harden pottery in a kiln
sense.examples: There he made and fired the pots while his wife glazed them. You'll want to fire the clay molds or stamps to bisque temps.
